div.p: From the earliest days of the Republic, Presidents have designated special diplomatic envoys for specific assignments, primarily overseas. The President appointed the first official specifically to bear the title of Ambassador at Large on Mar 12, 1949, under the authority vested in Article II, Section 2 of the U.S. Constitution that empowers the President, with the advice and consent of the Senate, to appoint Ambassadors, other public Ministers, and Consuls. Presidents have usually appointed Ambassadors at Large to deal with specific foreign policy issues which have been frequently, but not always, spelled out in their commissions. Functional designations are noted when they were included in an individual’s commission.

principal.note: Commissioned as Ambassador at Large for Foreign Economic Policy Development; later commissioned to serve concurrently as U.S. Permanent Representative to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.
Later commissioned to serve concurrently as Assistant Secretary of State for Congressional Relations.
Commissioned as Ambassador at Large for Law of the Sea Matters and Special Representative of the President for the Law of the Sea Conference, and Chief of Delegation.
Commissioned as Ambassador at Large and Special Representative of the President at the Law of the Sea Conference, and Chief of Delegation.
Commissioned as Ambassador at Large and U.S. Special Representative for Non-Proliferation Matters
Commissioned as Ambassador at Large and U.S. Representative to the Conference on Security and Cooperation in Europe, and Chairman of the U.S. Delegation.
Commissioned as Ambassador at Large and Coordinator for Economic Summit Affairs.
Commissioned as Ambassador at Large for Liaison with State and Local Governments.
Commissioned as Ambassador at Large and Coordinator for Refugee Affairs.
Commissioned as Ambassador at Large and Coordinator for Mexican Affairs.
Commissioned as Ambassador at Large and Coordinator for Refugee Affairs.
Commissioned as Ambassador at Large for Cultural Affairs.
Commissioned as U.S. Coordinator for Refugee Affairs and Ambassador at Large.
Commissioned as Ambassador at Large and Special Adviser to the Secretary on Non-Proliferation and Nuclear Energy Policy.
Commissioned as Ambassador at Large and Special Envoy for Central America.
Commissioned as Ambassador at Large and Special Envoy for Central America.
Commissioned as Ambassador at Large for Counter-Terrorism.
Commissioned as U.S. Coordinator for Refugee Affairs. After Dec 17, 1989, Lafontant became Lafontant-Mankarious.
Commissioned as Ambassador at Large for Burdensharing.
Commissioned as Ambassador at Large and Special Adviser to the Secretary on the New Independent States.

Not commissioned; nomination of Mar 8, 1982, was withdrawn before the Senate acted on it. Nominated as Ambassador at Large and Special Representative of the President for the Law of the Sea Conference, and Chief of Delegation.
